- VS Code Version: 1.39.2 (Mac)
- Log file (set `"trace": true` in launch config):
- Extension Version: 4.12.5

My current workspace is a C++ project so this extension is not applicable, gray and disabled. There had been nothing wrong for long time. But these days, maybe after some upgrade, the RELOAD REQUIRED button is always shown, no matter how many times I click it to reload Code, or even restart Code.

P.S. Another extionsion vscode-eslint has the same [issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/issues/878).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4645959/72673117-c7d49e80-3aa0-11ea-9b39-bdee48646454.png)

Working successfully with the debugger until 2 days ago. Still the same VS code version, but upgraded Node from 10.16 to 10.18, VS Code is still the same (1.41.1). 
When I start debugging, Chrome opens, displays about:blank, but with a "sad face" and it says it Crashed. VS Code says "Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000 ms - (reason: Got a response from target app, but no target pages found)." The app is running, if I open the "url" page in other chrome instance, it's there. I spent a day with googling it and tried all suggested solutions, but nothing works form me.
I've also tried to create some othere project from scratch (spfx by yeoman scaffolding) and the result is the same

With "runtimeArgs": ["--no-sandbox"] works like a charm, but I guess it shouldn't be used

Launch file here:
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost",
            "url": "http://localhost:3000/index.html?subsId=3708&action=modify&task=TaskName",
            "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "port": 4040,
            "trace": true
        }
    ]
}

- VS Code Version: 1.41.1
- Log file (set `"trace": true` in launch config):

2.

<!-- Breakpoints not working? The README has some tips. Please see the "Troubleshooting" section of the README before filing an issue. Especially the tip about using the `.scripts` command for debugging sourcemap issues. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.41.1
- It's a Vue CLI 3 project

Steps to reproduce:

1. Start debugging
2. Open Developer Tools

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
		{
			"type": "chrome",
			"request": "launch",
			"name": "VueJS: Chrome",
			"url": "http://localhost:8080",
			"userDataDir": "C:\\Users\\50l3r\\AppData\\Local\\Google\\Chrome\\User Data",
			"webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/src",
			"breakOnLoad": true,
			"sourceMapPathOverrides": {
				"webpack:///src/*": "${webRoot}/*"
			}
		}
    ]
}
```

[![Image from Gyazo](https://i.gyazo.com/ba2b583cdf9756240ef2857ec3e891f5.gif)](https://gyazo.com/ba2b583cdf9756240ef2857ec3e891f5)


Hi,
It would be more flexible to have this option **launchConfig**  rather than **debugWithChrome** in serverReadyAction and pass the url in argument to the other launch config. See the sample below

```json
       {
       ....
         "serverReadyAction": {
                "pattern": "(https://.+/\\w+)",
                "action": "launchConfig",
                "uriFormat": "%s",
                "name": "Attach to Client"
            }
        },
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Attach to Client",
            "port": 9222,
            "disableNetworkCache": true,
            "pathMapping": {
                "/sources/": "${workspaceFolder}/",
                "webapps/": "${workspaceFolder}/webdev/webapps/"
            }
        },
```

thanks
Hello there. I am have installed the Debugger for Chrome and am attempting to use it but for some reason I can seem to set bounding breakpoints within my app when have the Debugger for Chrome turned on.  I also can't F5 to bring up the Debugger when I want to use it. I am using VS Code version 1.40.2 on a Mac Book and when I press F5 or shift + F5 while in VS Code the debugger doesn't come up. 
My app is using 2 servers. TomCat for the Java code running in the backend and a node script to start the webpack build that injects the front end React code into to the Java project.

Here is an image of my launch.json file. 
<img width="1074" alt="Screen Shot 2019-12-05 at 11 28 01 AM" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30298592/70254039-6a83c880-1752-11ea-8338-70dbfb287ea3.png">

Debugging against a device (either Chrome or an in-app browser) via the Chrome/Edgium dev tools is quite tedious: bring up the dev tools, select "Remote Devices" from the "..." menu, wait for device to appear, select it, click 'Inspect' on the appropriate instance.

It would be nice to have a "Remote Device" launch/debug option in VSCode that at least skips straight to the device/instance selection part of the experience.
Breakpoints misbehave or get ignored when any change is done on Angular 8.2 code.
Same project don't show this issue if I install previous version of VSCode.

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.40.0
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start an Angular debugging session
2. Add breakpoints.
3. Live reload any changes.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes, except -obviusly- chrome debug

Building a Chrome webapp on a LAN based server, I'm attempting to use vscode's debugger to debug the application. It's built with Vue, Typescript and Webpack.

Everything seems to work, but when I set a breakpoint in one of my Vue SFC's, the breakpoint breaks into (and loads) my compiled app.js file. I've tried a variety of workarounds, but whatever I change in sourceMapPathOverrides seems to break things (ie. breakpoints don't work any more). I'm wondering if this issue is related to #78 or #85 because my issue seems similar especially to the latter.

Dev folder loaded into vscode (ie. ${workspaceFolder}) is `\\server\sites\elog.local`

The app is loaded from the url `https://elog.local/appv1/123`

Couple of issues I've picked up (see .scripts output below). In webpack:/// and webpack-generated:/// sourcemap entries, the given path for files seems to take the form `\\server\sites\elog.local\resources\app\appv1\webpack:\resources\app\components\xxx.vue` which seems incorrect to me as the path `\\server\sites\elog.local\resources\app\appv1` does not exist. I spotted an error about 'sourceRoot' not found in the trace logs, however changing 'sourceRoot' in tsconfig.json makes no difference and the same error still appears in the log.

FWIW everything seems to work correctly in Chrome. If I use the debugger, navigate to sources, webpack-debug://source//resources/app/components/TabLogbook.vue and set a breakpoint, Chrome breaks correctly, although it only shows the `<script>` section of the Vue SFC.

Webpack config and tsconfig can be supplied if that helps. I'm wondering if the UNC paths (editing across smb share) is part of the problem, ie. is this a bug or config related?

TIA for any help!

launch.json:
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Eloggist-Chrome",
            "url": "https://elog.local/appv1/123",
            "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/resources/app",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "trace": true,
            "sourceMapPathOverrides": {
                "webpack-debug:///source/resources/app/*": "${webRoot}/*",
            }
        }
    ]
}
```

.scripts (vendor.js and manifest.js removed):

```
[11:36:34.470 UTC] ← From target: {"method":"Console.messageAdded","params":{"message":{"source":"console-api","level":"log","text":"AppDb.init_db() - initiating firstrun...","url":"https://elog.local/appv1/app.js","line":3827,"column":21}}}

```
<!-- Breakpoints not working? The README has some tips. Please see the "Troubleshooting" section of the README before filing an issue. Especially the tip about using the `.scripts` command for debugging sourcemap issues. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.40.1
- Log file (set `"trace": true` in launch config): [vscode-chrome-debug.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-chrome-debug/files/3845555/vscode-chrome-debug.txt)



Steps to reproduce:

1. `cd` to an empty folder
2.  `yarn create react-app .` to create a fresh react app
3. test code:
```javascript
import './App.css';
import React, { useState } from 'react';

function App() {
  const [date, setDate] = useState(new Date().toString());

  return (
    <div className="App">
      <p>{date}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setDate(new Date().toString())}>now</button>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;
```
4. Set some breakpoints
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7919562/68840192-2d9d5680-06fd-11ea-9990-917b0e921266.png)  
5. ok now create `launch.json`, all using default config     
```jsonc
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost",
            "url": "http://<remote_host_ip>:3030",
            "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}"
        }
    ]
}
```
I modified the `url` field to make sure Chrome in local can navigate to target devserver.
6. `yarn start` to start devserver  
7. launch debugger  
8. App running perfectly ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7919562/68840634-11e68000-06fe-11ea-8300-ccda5a72464f.png)  
but all breakpoints were ignored and debugger show me "breakpoint set but not yet bound"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7919562/68840752-4c501d00-06fe-11ea-9913-a2ba9186c32e.png)  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7919562/68840783-5a9e3900-06fe-11ea-91cf-42993464e317.png)

Workspace Path: `/mnt/work/Project/test/reacttest2`
</details>

There should be a way to set the `runtimeExecutable` as a user config for the extension. That way you could set it up once instead of doing it for every new project, in case you don't have Chrome installed to one of the default paths.
